linkTarget.anchoringText: It becauses that many wells in Central Palembang Sub Basin did not reach or penetrate depth of Talang Akar formation. The well data consisted of core data, SCAL, salinity water analysis, biostratigraphy, wireline log (LAS data), petrography description, mudlog, final well report, completion report, pressure test data, and well test report. Fig. 1 presented map of the well position distribution and sub basin configuration in South Sumatera Basin.

image-wrap.label: Figure 1
image-wrap.caption: Structural Map of Basement in South Sumatera Basin (modified after LAPI-ITB and BPMIGAS 2004). The map shows that South Sumatera Basin and Well Data Distribution Used in This Research. South Sumatera Basin is divided into Jambi Sub basin, North Palembang Sub Basin, Central Palembang Sub Basin, and South Palembang Sub Basin. It indicated four major paleo-structural orientations consisting of NE-SW, WNW-ESE, N-S and NW-SE orientation.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Structural Map of Basement in South Sumatera Basin (modified after LAPI-ITB and BPMIGAS 2004). The map shows that South Sumatera Basin and Well Data Distribution Used in This Research. South Sumatera Basin is divided into Jambi Sub basin, North Palembang Sub Basin, Central Palembang Sub Basin, and South Palembang Sub Basin. It indicated four major paleo-structural orientations consisting of NE-SW, WNW-ESE, N-S and NW-SE orientation.

linkTarget.anchoringText: The methods used to test the hypothesis included regional well correlation, petrophysical analysis, core and cutting description, petrography analysis, petrophysical cross plot and cut-off analysis, and well test data analysis validation. This method should provide the understanding of petrophysic role of LRPZ of Talang Akar Formation. The workflow of this study is presented simply on Fig. 2.

image-wrap.label: Figure 2
image-wrap.caption: Research Workflow of Talang Akar Formation LRPZ (Low Resistivity Pay Zone)

formatted-caption.caption-text: Research Workflow of Talang Akar Formation LRPZ (Low Resistivity Pay Zone)

linkTarget.anchoringText: South Sumatera Basin is bounded by crystalline basement and Pre-Tertiary metasediment of Tigapuluh High in the northwest, the Asian Plate; on the southeast edge of the Sunda Shelf (Lingga Island and Bangka) in the northeast, the Bukit Barisan Mountains and Garba Mountains in the south and west, and bounded by Lampung High in the southeast. The position of South Sumatra Basin geographically and its tectonic element boundary can be seen in Fig. 3.

image-wrap.label: Figure 3
image-wrap.caption: Tectonic Setting of the South Sumatera Basin (SSB) also Relationship to the Surrounding Island (modified after Hamilton 1979). South Sumatra Basin is located between Tigapuluh Mountain in the northwest and Lampung High in the southeast.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Tectonic Setting of the South Sumatera Basin (SSB) also Relationship to the Surrounding Island (modified after Hamilton 1979). South Sumatra Basin is located between Tigapuluh Mountain in the northwest and Lampung High in the southeast.

linkTarget.anchoringText: From old to young age, stratigraphy of South Sumatera Basin is composed of basement rock; crystalline lithology type (igneous rock and metamorphic rock) and metasediment (Ryacudu 2005). Then, it is followed by sedimentation in Tertiary, consisting of Lahat Formation and Lemat Formation, Talang Akar Formation, Baturaja Formation, Gumai Formation, Air Benakat Formation, Muaraenim Formation, and Kasai Formation as seen on Fig. 4.

image-wrap.label: Figure 4
image-wrap.caption: General Stratigraphy and Tectonostratigraphy of South Sumatera Basin ( Ryacudu 2005 ).

formatted-caption.caption-text: General Stratigraphy and Tectonostratigraphy of South Sumatera Basin ( Ryacudu 2005 ).

linkTarget.bib:
Ryacudu, 2005
R. Ryacudu
2005. Studi Endapan Syn-Rift Paleogen di Cekungan Sumatera Selatan. Dissertation , Bandung Institute of Technology, West Java, Indonesia.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Using stratigraphy sequence correlation method, regional well correlation was conducted covering all of sub basin in South Sumatera Basin. A complete section of Talang Akar formation (TAF) from Lower Talang Akar to Upper Talang Akar only found in Jambi sub basin and South Palembang sub basin, while in two others sub basin lower Talang Akar has not been explore yet. Regional well correlation of Talang Akar Formation inter sub basin is presented on Fig. 5. In this study, stratigraphy sequence correlation just only defines sequence boundary (SB) and maximum-flooding surface (MFS) based on stratigraphic pattern observed on gamma ray, density, and neutron log.

image-wrap.label: Figure 5
image-wrap.caption: Regional Well Correlation (NW-SE) of Talang Akar Formation Inter Sub Basin Intergated Using Stratigraphy Sequence Correlation Method Approach.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Regional Well Correlation (NW-SE) of Talang Akar Formation Inter Sub Basin Intergated Using Stratigraphy Sequence Correlation Method Approach.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Based on log data, true resistivity log (RT) shows variation of resistivity value in South Sumatera Basin (Fig. 6). Fig. 6 identifies two groups of resistivity value in South Sumatera Basin: High Resistivity Pay and Low Resistivity Pay. Based on well test result statistically (Fig. 6), chance of success for LRPZ is lower than High Resistivity Pay Zone (HRPZ) in South Sumatera Basin. True resistivity (RT) comparation between success well test cases and failed well test cases (wet test) indicates that RT can not be used as single data, but it need to be integrated with the other data to determine reservoir pay zone (indicating for flowing hydrocarbon) for well testing interval candidates.

image-wrap.label: Figure 6
image-wrap.caption: True Resistivity (RT) Variation of Talang Akar Formation in South Sumatera Basin.

formatted-caption.caption-text: True Resistivity (RT) Variation of Talang Akar Formation in South Sumatera Basin.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Observation to log and mudlog data demonstrated relationship between Resistivity and Total Gas Reading (Fig. 7), also between Resistivity and Mud Weight (Fig. 8) in Talang Akar Formation, South Sumatera Basin. The data used in Fig. 7 and Fig. 8 comes from well testing interval, both of success and failure. In general, Fig. 7 indicated that the high total gas reading (10-5000 units) is generally associated with resistivity values ranging from 5-100 ohm.m in each of sub-basin.

image-wrap.label: Figure 7
image-wrap.caption: Resistivity vs Total Gas Reading Cross-Plot of Talang Akar Formation Reservoir Interval in South Sumatera Basin. The cross-plot shows comparison of relationship between resistivity and total gas reading in North Palembang, South Palembang, and Jambi Sub Basin.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Resistivity vs Total Gas Reading Cross-Plot of Talang Akar Formation Reservoir Interval in South Sumatera Basin. The cross-plot shows comparison of relationship between resistivity and total gas reading in North Palembang, South Palembang, and Jambi Sub Basin.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Observation to log and mudlog data demonstrated relationship between Resistivity and Total Gas Reading (Fig. 7), also between Resistivity and Mud Weight (Fig. 8) in Talang Akar Formation, South Sumatera Basin. The data used in Fig. 7 and Fig. 8 comes from well testing interval, both of success and failure. In general, Fig. 7 indicated that the high total gas reading (10-5000 units) is generally associated with resistivity values ranging from 5-100 ohm.m in each of sub-basin.

image-wrap.label: Figure 8
image-wrap.caption: Resistivity vs Mud weight Cross-Plot of Talang Akar Formation Reservoir Interval in South Sumatera Basin. The cross-plot shows comparison of relationship between resistivity and mud weight

formatted-caption.caption-text: Resistivity vs Mud weight Cross-Plot of Talang Akar Formation Reservoir Interval in South Sumatera Basin. The cross-plot shows comparison of relationship between resistivity and mud weight

linkTarget.anchoringText: Correlation between inter-various log data was conducted to identify LRPZ behavior of Talang Akar Formation in South Sumatera basin (Fig. 9A, Fig. 9B, Fig. 10A, and Fig. 10B). Fig. 9A and Fig. 10A identified that LRPZ with resistivity <5 ohm.m is characterized by low Gamma Ray (GR) value (<160 API dominantly). Relationship between neutron and density log data presented on Fig. 9B and Fig. 10B described that neutron and density log show value variation or random distribution, both of successful well test and failed well test case. It means that there are not certain value cut off for neutron and density log for characterizing LRPZ in Talang Akar Formation, South Sumatera Basin.

image-wrap.label: Figure 9
image-wrap.caption: (A) GR vs Resistivity vs Density Cross-Plot. (B) GR vs Neutron vs Density Cross-Plot. Log data of the cross-plots is on Talang Akar Formation reservoir pay interval tested in South Sumatera Basin.

formatted-caption.caption-text: (A) GR vs Resistivity vs Density Cross-Plot. (B) GR vs Neutron vs Density Cross-Plot. Log data of the cross-plots is on Talang Akar Formation reservoir pay interval tested in South Sumatera Basin.

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: GR vs Resistivity vs Density Cross-Plot.
GR vs Neutron vs Density Cross-Plo

linkTarget.anchoringText: Correlation between inter-various log data was conducted to identify LRPZ behavior of Talang Akar Formation in South Sumatera basin (Fig. 9A, Fig. 9B, Fig. 10A, and Fig. 10B). Fig. 9A and Fig. 10A identified that LRPZ with resistivity <5 ohm.m is characterized by low Gamma Ray (GR) value (<160 API dominantly). Relationship between neutron and density log data presented on Fig. 9B and Fig. 10B described that neutron and density log show value variation or random distribution, both of successful well test and failed well test case. It means that there are not certain value cut off for neutron and density log for characterizing LRPZ in Talang Akar Formation, South Sumatera Basin.

image-wrap.label: Figure 10
image-wrap.caption: (A) GR vs Resistivity vs Neutron Cross-Plot. (B) Resistivity vs Neutron vs Density Cross-Plot. Log data of the cross-plots is on Talang Akar Formation reservoir pay interval tested in South Sumatera Basin.

formatted-caption.caption-text: (A) GR vs Resistivity vs Neutron Cross-Plot. (B) Resistivity vs Neutron vs Density Cross-Plot. Log data of the cross-plots is on Talang Akar Formation reservoir pay interval tested in South Sumatera Basin.

Resistivity vs Neutron vs Density Cross-Plot.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Mudlog data indicated high total gas reading and oil show in LRPZ. Petrophysical analysis was conducted to characterize LRPZ integrated with mudlog analysis in this research. Petrophysical analysis and mudlog data presented that LRPZ is characterized by low Gamma Ray, neutron and density cross-over, low resistivity, high total gas reading, and oil show indication as presented on Fig. 11 and Fig. 12.

image-wrap.label: Figure 11
image-wrap.caption: Petrophysical Analysis Model of LRPZ Based on LR-1Well in South Palembang Sub Basin Integrated with Mudlog Data.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Petrophysical Analysis Model of LRPZ Based on LR-1Well in South Palembang Sub Basin Integrated with Mudlog Data.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Mudlog data indicated high total gas reading and oil show in LRPZ. Petrophysical analysis was conducted to characterize LRPZ integrated with mudlog analysis in this research. Petrophysical analysis and mudlog data presented that LRPZ is characterized by low Gamma Ray, neutron and density cross-over, low resistivity, high total gas reading, and oil show indication as presented on Fig. 11 and Fig. 12.

image-wrap.label: Figure 12
image-wrap.caption: Petrophysical Analysis Model of LRPZ Based on LR-7 Well in Jambi Sub Basin Integrated with Mudlog Data.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Petrophysical Analysis Model of LRPZ Based on LR-7 Well in Jambi Sub Basin Integrated with Mudlog Data.

linkTarget.anchoringText: LRPZ inventarization and distribution were conducted to understand behavior and cause of LRPZ phenomenon in South Sumatera Basin in overall. Based on 110 wells used in this research, it can be inventorized that there are 7 (seven) wells are categorized as LRPZ in Talang Akar formation, South Sumatera Basin. Seven wells consists of 3 (three) wells distributed in South Palembang Sub Basin and 4 (four) wells distributed in Jambi Sub Basin. LRPZ inventarization and distribution are presented on Fig. 13.

image-wrap.label: Figure 13
image-wrap.caption: LRPZ Inventarization and Distribution of Talang Akar Formation in South Sumatera Basin

formatted-caption.caption-text: LRPZ Inventarization and Distribution of Talang Akar Formation in South Sumatera Basin

linkTarget.anchoringText: In this research, cutting, core, and petrography description was analyzed to observe mineralogy (especially conductive mineral), sediment provenance, and depositional environment. Lithology description of LR-1 and A-1 well is used as a key well to analyze the causes of LRPZ in Talang Akar formation. Talang Akar well cutting description in LR-1 and A-1 can be observed on Table 1 and Table 2. A-1 well is representative of HRPZ (High Resistivity Pay Zone) well in South Palembang Sub Basin Sub Basin. LR-1 is representative of LRPZ (Low Resistivity Pay Zone) well in Jambi Sub Basin. Based on Table 1 and Table 2, either A-1 well (HRPZ well) or LR-1 well (LRPZ well) indicated glauconite mineral content in cutting description of Talang Akar. Based on petrography analysis of LR-1 well sidewall core (Fig. 14),

image-wrap.label: Figure 14
image-wrap.caption: Petrography Analysis of LR-1 Well Sidewall Core in Talang Akar Formation

formatted-caption.caption-text: Petrography Analysis of LR-1 Well Sidewall Core in Talang Akar Formation

linkTarget.anchoringText: Thus, by inputting properties of the "pure" sand and shale end-members this model can be used to infer the shale distribution within the rock and therefore provide evidence of fine-scaled lamination. In this research, shale distribution model was built using the Thomas and Stieber (1975) model presented on Fig. 15A and Fig. 15 B. This approach has come to identify the shale type by using Vcl and PHIE as axes, which then will help to describe what causes the LRP in South Sumatera Basin. Fig. 15A and Fig. 15 B explain that Talang Akar formation in South Sumatera Basin has a dispersed-laminated shale type reservoir dominantly. Fig. 15A and Fig. 15 B show that Talang Akar reservoir interval is mainly composed by Dispersedâ€“Laminated shale. It indicates the causes controlling LRPZ of Talang Akar in South Sumatera Basin is fine grained, or superficial microporosity.
linkTarget.label: Figure 15

image-wrap.caption: (A) Shale Distribution Model (Thommas-Stieber); (B) Shale Distribution Model Based on Study Observation Result

formatted-caption.caption-text: (A) Shale Distribution Model (Thommas-Stieber); (B) Shale Distribution Model Based on Study Observation Result

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: Shale Distribution Model Based on Study Observation Result

linkTarget.anchoringText: In addition, mudlog data is a hard data absolutely required to determine the LRPZ integrated in petro physical analysis. Petrophysical analysis model of LRPZ in Talang Akar is represented on Fig. 16.Fig. 16 shows that Pseudo archie decreases water saturation (Sw) down to 70%, while the DST (Drill Stem Test) concludes a successful test. This occurred in several other wells coincidently, which suggested economic cut off for LRPZ is 70% for water saturation (Sw) in LRPZ of Talang Akar.

image-wrap.label: Figure 16
image-wrap.caption: Petrophysical Analysis Model of LRPZ Using Pseudo Archi Approach in LR-1 Well

formatted-caption.caption-text: Petrophysical Analysis Model of LRPZ Using Pseudo Archi Approach in LR-1 Well

linkTarget.anchoringText: n this study, resistivity value readings in true resistivity (RT) which is used as the cut off value is obtained from the LRPZ wells reference validated by well test result. Based on all of analysis above, it was found that the resistivity limit value is used as the threshold of LRPZ interval in RPD cross-plot is 5 ohmm. Based on the results crossplot two of these parameters (RPD and RT) presented on Fig. 17, the interval LRPZ in all sub- basins in South Sumatra Basin can be detected by performing shading based on a threshold value obtained from the test results with RDP > 0 and resistivity values < 5 ohm.m. The shading results can be validated directly on some wells using flagging, so LRPZ other zones can be detected in all wells.

image-wrap.label: Figure 17
image-wrap.caption: LRPZ Flagging Using RPD (Relative Porosity Difference) Approach

formatted-caption.caption-text: LRPZ Flagging Using RPD (Relative Porosity Difference) Approach
